content: how do I unzip from termial
unzip file.zip
how to check if a file is sorted alphabetically
sort -C file.txt
what if Have a .tsv file
sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 file.tsv
how to check if two tsv file are the same
diff file1.tsv file2.tsv
how to put the output of a command into a tsv file
command > output.tsv
can you make a command that sort all tsv file and csend the output into another file called .tsv. Do this for all the following names: italy england france portugal turkey

sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 italy.tsv > sorted_italy.tsv

sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 england.tsv > sorted_england.tsv

sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 france.tsv > sorted_france.tsv

sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 portugal.tsv > sorted_portugal.tsv

sort -t $'\t' -k1,1 turkey.tsv > sorted_turkey.tsv

cat sorted_italy.tsv sorted_england.tsv sorted_france.tsv sorted_portugal.tsv sorted_turkey.tsv > all_sorted.tsv
a loop that executes the command: diff @name sorted_@name.tsv for the follwing names: italy france portugal turkey england
for name in italy france portugal turkey england; do diff $name.tsv sorted_$name.tsv; done
how to sort a tsv file based on the second value of every row
sort -t $'\t' -k2,2 file.tsv
after sorting can you put the first 3 rows in a file called targets.txt
sort -t $'\t' -k2,2 file.tsv | head -n 3 > targets.txt
great, can you make a loop that does those commands for every of the following file: england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv
for file in england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv; do sort -t $'\t' -k2,2 $file | head -n 3 > targets.txt; done
can you give me the same loop but the sorting is in descreasing order
for file in england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv; do sort -t $'\t' -k2,2 -r $file | head -n 3 > targets.txt; done
instead of overwriting can you append the head of every file into target.txt?
for file in england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv; do sort -t $'\t' -k2,2 -r $file | head -n 3 >> targets.txt; done
can you sort numerical string by their numerical value?

Yes, you can use the -n option with the sort command to sort numerical strings by their numerical value. For example:

sort -n file.txt
great, can you give me the same loop from before but the second column needs to be intepred and sortedas a numerical value
for file in england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv; do sort -t $'\t' -k2,2n -r $file | head -n 3 >> targets.txt; done
but in decreasing order for the second column (numerical value)
for file in england.tsv france.tsv portugal.tsv; do sort -t $'\t' -k2,2rn $file | head -n 3 >> targets.txt; done
encript the resulting target.txt file using the open ssl tool and set the encription key as geronimo. Save the encripted file as targets.enc
openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in targets.txt -out targets.enc -k geronimo
remove everything from this folder apart from targets.enc

You can use the following command to remove all files in the current directory except for targets.enc:

```
rm !(targets.enc)
``` 

Note that this command requires the `extglob` shell option to be enabled. You can enable it by running:

```
shopt -s extglob
``` 

If you want to remove all files and subdirectories recursively, you can use the following command:

```
rm -r !(targets.enc)
``` 

Again, make sure to enable the `extglob` shell option before running this command.
open a connection ssh with localhost port 2222
ssh localhost -p 2222
my username for this server is john, can you give me the commands agin

Sure! The command to open an SSH connection with localhost on port 2222 using the username "john" is:

```
ssh john@localhost -p 2222
```
can you copy in this folder all the files that starts with a in the home directory of joh@localhost -p 2222

Yes, you can use the `scp` command to copy files from a remote server to your local machine. The command to copy all files that start with "a" from the home directory of user "john" on the remote server to your current directory on your local machine is:

```
scp john@localhost:/home/john/a* .
```

This assumes that you have already established an SSH connection to the remote server using the `ssh` command. If you haven't done so already, you can use the command I provided earlier to establish the connection:

```
ssh john@localhost -p 2222
```
how to specify the port in the scp command

You can specify the port number for the `scp` command using the `-P` option, followed by the port number. For example, to copy a file named "file.txt" from a remote server with IP address 192.168.1.100 on port 2222 to your current directory on your local machine, you can use the following command:

```
scp -P 2222 user@192.168.1.100:/path/to/file.txt .
```

Replace "user" with the username on the remote server, and "/path/to/file.txt" with the path to the file you want to copy. The dot at the end of the command specifies the current directory on your local machine as the destination for the copied file.
how to downalod all the files from the home directory of a ssh server

You can use the `scp` command with the `-r` option to download all files from a remote directory to your local machine. For example, to download all files from the home directory of user "john" on a remote server with IP address 192.168.1.100 on port 2222, you can use the following command:

```
scp -r -P 2222 john@192.168.1.100:~ .
```

This will copy all files and directories from the home directory of user "john" on the remote server to your current directory on your local machine. The dot at the end of the command specifies the current directory as the destination for the copied files.
make sure that wow.sh script has its permissios set to 755

You can use the `chmod` command to set the permissions of the `wow.sh` script to 755. The command is:

```
chmod 755 wow.sh
```

This will give the owner of the file (usually you) read, write, and execute permissions, and give read and execute permissions to the group and others.
copy the wow.sh script to the localhost server

Assuming that you want to copy the `wow.sh` script from your local machine to a remote server using `scp`, you can use the following command:

```
scp wow.sh user@localhost:/path/to/destination
```

Replace "user" with the username on the remote server, and "/path/to/destination" with the path to the directory where you want to copy the file. If you want to copy the file to the home directory of the remote user, you can use `~` as the destination path. For example:

```
scp wow.sh user@localhost:~
```

This will copy the `wow.sh` script to the home directory of the remote user.
copy the scirpt wow.sh to the john@localhost -p 222 server

You can use the following command to copy the `wow.sh` script from your local machine to the home directory of user "john" on the remote server at `localhost` on port 2222 using `scp`:

```
scp -P 2222 wow.sh john@localhost:~
```

This assumes that you have already established an SSH connection to the remote server using the `ssh` command. If you haven't done so already, you can use the command I provided earlier to establish the connection:

```
ssh john@localhost -p 2222
```
